136.text: been missing is the voices of the workers themselves.

278.text: the alienation of the worker from the product of his labor.

282.text: Unlike, say, a traditional maker of shoes or cabinets,

310.text: What she does with the money she earns,

313.text: what she learns in that place, and how it changes her,

316.text: these are the things that matter.

558.text: The first time I met Min, she had just turned 18

562.text: and quit her first job on the assembly line

567.text: Over the next two years, I watched as she switched jobs

569.text: five times, eventually landing a lucrative post

572.text: in the purchasing department of a hardware factory.

576.text: Later, she married a fellow migrant worker,

578.text: moved with him to his village,

583.text: and saved enough money to buy a secondhand Buick

585.text: for herself and an apartment for her parents.

589.text: She recently returned to Dongguan on her own

592.text: to take a job in a factory that makes construction cranes,

596.text: temporarily leaving her husband and children

600.text: In a recent email to me, she explained,

603.text: "A person should have some ambition while she is young

607.text: so that in old age she can look back on her life

609.text: and feel that it was not lived to no purpose."

614.text: Across China, there are 150 million workers like her,

619.text: one third of them women, who have left their villages

621.text: to work in the factories, the hotels, the restaurants

625.text: and the construction sites of the big cities.

628.text: Together, they make up the largest migration in history,

631.text: and it is globalization, this chain that begins

637.text: and ends with iPhones in our pockets and Nikes on our feet

641.text: and Coach handbags on our arms

643.text: that has changed the way these millions of people

645.text: work and marry and live and think.

650.text: Very few of them would want to go back

652.text: to the way things used to be.

655.text: When I first went to Dongguan, I worried that

658.text: it would be depressing to spend so much time with workers.

662.text: I also worried that nothing would ever happen to them,

665.text: or that they would have nothing to say to me.

668.text: Instead, I found young women who were smart and funny

673.text: By opening up their lives to me,

676.text: they taught me so much about factories

678.text: and about China and about how to live in the world.
